Published by Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group. 2025 The Author(s) https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial License ( http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ ABSTRACT Environmental factors can influence gene expression and developmental outcomes through epigenetic modifications. Although maternal diet influences offspring DNA methylation and phenotypes, its effects on the oocyte and the resulting embryonic epigenome remain poorly understood. Here, we investigated the effect of maternal methionine supplementation on DNA methylation patterns in oocytes and embryos in Polypay sheep. Whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) was performed on oocytes collected from 16 twin ewe pairs (8 methionine-treated and 8 controls). These ewes were later bred to control rams, and embryos were flushed for WGBS as well. In oocytes, 2,056 differentially methylated cytosines (DMCs) were identified. Additionally, 17 mitochondrial DMCs were identified, with 12 hypermethylated and 5 hypomethylated. In embryos, 113 DMCs were identified. Mitochondrial DNA analysis revealed 22 hypermethylated DMCs. To assess the inheritance of methyl marks, we compared DMCs between oocytes and embryos. While no direct overlaps were found in nuclear DNA, 3 CpGs exhibited opposite methylation trends – hypomethylated in oocytes but hypermethylated in embryos. In contrast, 5 mitochondrial DMCs overlapped between oocytes and embryos. In a low-protein mouse model, van Straten and colleagues demonstrated that 204 gene promoter regions were differentially methylated in the livers of fetuses derived from low-protein dams compared to control dams [ 21 22 23 24 25 While the effects of maternal diet on offspring are relatively well understood, the specific impact of dietary factors on the epigenetic landscape of germ cells and, consequently, on the resulting embryos warrants further evaluation. Schutt and colleagues demonstrated that a protein-restricted diet in rats resulted in altered amino acid metabolism in the oocyte along with abnormal cumulus oocyte complex mitochondrial ultrastructure, and differential oocyte expression of genes related to mitochondria biogenesis [ 26 27 28 28 29 While these studies collectively demonstrate that maternal dietary changes can influence both the oocyte and offspring’s health, there is a notable gap in our understanding of how specific dietary components, such as the methyl group donor methionine, affect the whole-genome methylation landscape of the oocyte. Furthermore, little is known about how these methylation changes are inherited by the embryo and whether they impact the development of both the embryo and the offspring. The knowledge gap is particularly significant in livestock species, as most work to date has utilized rodent models. In a previous study in cows, we demonstrated that adding dietary methionine at the preimplantation stage of embryo development altered the expression of 276 genes in the collected embryos, highlighting the potential impact of maternal methionine supplementation on embryonic development [ 30 31 Materials and methods This study was conducted in accordance with the ARRIVE 2.0 guidelines for the reporting of animal research. All procedures involving animals were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of the University of Wisconsin-Madison (Protocol ID: A006488-R01). Supplementation of rumen-protected methionine (RPM) in diets of ewes In this study, Polypay sheep was used as a large animal model as it has long been known for its reproductive efficiency, twinning rate, and prolificacy. In previous studies, we utilized this model to study the effects of paternal and maternal methionine supplementation on epigenetic and phenotypic changes in offspring [ 31 32 Figure 1 n n 32 31 32 33 Figure 1. A graphical representation of experimental design of the study including methionine supplementation (1), oocyte collection (2), in vivo embryo production and collection (3), constructing sample pools for whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (4), sequence alignment and quality control (5), differential methylation analysis (6), and in-vitro embryo production and qPCR (7). Ovarian stimulation protocol To maximize the number of follicles available for OPU, the ewes underwent ovarian stimulation prior to the procedure. On Day 0, a controlled internal drug release (CIDR) was inserted vaginally into each ewe. On Day 9, 1.0 cc of Estrumate was administered to induce luteolysis. Starting on Day 10.5, ewes received 3.0 cc of Folltropin via intramuscular injection, followed by two 2.0 cc injections on Day 11. Ovarian aspirations were performed on Day 12, and the CIDR was removed. Ovum pick up Ovum pick up was performed 76 days after the start of methionine supplementation via laparotomy on Day 12 of the ovarian stimulation protocol. The ewes were fasted for 24 hours before surgery. General anesthesia was induced with an intravenous injection of 2–4 mg/kg of Propofol, followed by maintenance with inhalation of the anesthetic, isoflurane. Once intubated, the ewes were then placed in a Trendelenburg position to facilitate optimal access to the ovaries before incisions were made. A 2 cc injection of Bupivacaine was administered at the laparoscopic incision sites for local anesthesia, and Flunixin Meglumine was given intravenously for postoperative pain relief and to minimize swelling. Within 5 minutes of Bupivacaine administration, approximately 3 1-inch incisions were made in the abdominal wall, spaced about 3 inches apart. A laparoscope was inserted into one incision, and a small amount of CO2 gas was used to slightly inflate the abdomen. A second laparoscope, equipped with a dissecting tool, was inserted through a second incision to grab the ovarian ligament. Both laparoscopes were used for visualizing the ovaries, and abdominal pressure was continuously monitored to ensure it did not exceed 10 cm H2O. A trocar attached to an OPU kit connected to a vacuum pump was inserted through the third incision, and follicular aspiration was performed, starting from the bottom of each ovary and moving upwards. Following aspiration of each ovary, the collection tube was rinsed with warmed flush media by inserting the OPU needle tip into the flush media. Prior to the release of the ovarian ligament, the ovaries were then rinsed with heparinized saline (1 ml/50 ml), and the musculature and skin were sutured. Following the OPU, oocytes were washed in ABT Complete Flush Media (ABT360, Pullman, WA, USA) and evaluated for quality according to the standards outlined by the International Embryo Technology Society (IETS). Grade 1 and 2 oocytes were then pooled by treatment and placed into a 0.5 mL tube in 1–2 uL of media for DNA extraction and sequencing. To provide sufficient DNA amount for whole genome bisulfite sequencing and unbiased representation, collected oocytes were sequenced as a pool rather than a single oocyte. Three treatment and four control pools were made out of all collected oocytes. Briefly, two treatment pools had oocytes from three methionine-fed ewes each, and the other one had oocytes from the remaining two treatment ewes. Additionally, three control pools had oocytes from two control ewes each, and the remaining control consisted of only one ewe’s oocytes, since the last control ewe did not yield any oocytes. A pooling strategy was applied, considering a similar number of oocytes represented in each pool, ranging from 17 to 21 oocytes. Synchronization and superovulation protocol To maximize the number of embryos for DNA methylation analysis, the same ewes used for OPU underwent estrus synchronization and superovulation prior to breeding. On Day 0, a CIDR was inserted vaginally into each ewe. On Day 7, the CIDR was replaced with a new one, and 1.0 cc of prostaglandin (EstroPLAN) was administered to induce luteolysis. Starting on Day 12, Folltropin was administered twice daily for four days. The CIDR was removed on Day 14.5, and 1.5 cc of PG600 was given to stimulate ovulation. On Day 16, ewes were introduced to a control yearling Polypay ram for natural mating. Each ram was randomly selected to breed with four ewes and was fitted with marking harnesses to confirm mating success. Embryo flushes Embryo collections were performed by GenOvations (Lodi, WI, USA) via laparotomy 70 days after the OPU procedure. Prior to surgery, ewes were fasted for 24 hours, and general anesthesia was administered as described above. Once intubated and in a Trendelenburg position, local anesthetic and Flunixin were administered as previously described, and a small (~1.5 cm) incision was made in the abdominal wall. A laparoscope was inserted through the incision to visualize the uterus, and the incision was then enlarged to approximately 7 cm to allow access through the subcutaneous tissue, abdominal musculature, and peritoneum. The uterine horns were then exposed, and a 20-G Foley catheter was inserted into the distal third of each uterine horn. A total of 50 ml of saline was flushed through each horn and collected into a filtered Petri dish via the Foley catheter. The uterine horns were repositioned into the abdomen, and the musculature and skin were sutured closed. Following the flush, blastocysts were washed in ABT Complete Flush Media (ABT360), evaluated using the IETS grading system, and placed into a 0.5 mL tube containing 1- 2 uL of media for DNA extraction and sequencing. Three treatment and five control pools were made. Briefly, two treatment pools had embryos from two methionine-fed ewes each, and the other one had embryos from one treatment ewe, as the remaining three did not yield any embryos. Additionally, three control pools had embryos from two control ewes each, and the remaining two control pools consisted only of one ewe’s embryos each. A pooling strategy was applied, considering a similar number of embryos represented in each pool, containing 10 to 13 embryos. Whole-genome DNA methylation analysis of oocytes and embryos Oocyte and embryo samples were processed for whole-genome bisulfite sequencing (WGBS) using the EZ DNA Methylation Direct Kit (Zymo Research, Irvine, CA, USA), which enables bisulfite conversion directly from cells without the need for prior DNA purification. Following bisulfite conversion, whole genome amplification was performed using the Pico Methyl-Seq Library Prep Kit (Zymo Research) to ensure sufficient DNA for downstream analysis. The amplification was followed by adapter ligation and PCR amplification to prepare the sequencing libraries. Sequencing was performed at the Roy J. Carver Biotechnology Center, The University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, using the NovaSeq X Plus platform (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA) with two 25B lanes, using V1.0 sequencing kits. Fastq files were generated and demultiplexed using the bcl2fastq v2.20 Conversion Software (Illumina) for downstream analysis. Bioinformatics analysis Following WGBS, the 150 bp paired-end reads for 8 blastocyst stage embryo pools (5 control, 3 treatment) and 7 oocyte pools (4 control, 3 treatment) were processed using FastQC v0.12.1 to generate sequence quality reports. TrimGalore v0.6.1 and Cutadapt v4.8 were utilized for trimming any low-quality bases, reads, and adapter sequences [ 34–36 37 38 Differentially methylated cytosines (DMCs) within CpG islands of both nuclear and mitochondrial genomes from oocytes and embryos were identified using the methylKit R package. Comparisons were performed between control and treatment groups for embryo pools, oocyte pools, and their respective mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) [ 39 40 41 After detecting DMCs, the ‘ARS-UI_Ramb_v3.0’ reference genome annotations were used with the R packages ‘genomation’ and ‘GenomicRanges’ to analyse the distribution of methylation differences across gene components (e.g., promoters, introns, exons, intergenic regions). To validate the effects across species, bovine ovaries were sourced from a local abattoir. In vitro embryo production was performed as previously described by Tribulo et al. For this procedure, zygotes were removed from the culture plate in groups of 40 and washed twice in HEPES-TALP, followed by 3 washes in Opti-MEM (Gibco, Waltham, MA, USA). Each group was then passed through 2 sequential 5.7 µL drops containing Opti-MEM supplemented with custom-designed siRNAs (QIAGEN, Germantown, MD, USA) at a final concentration of 10 µM. This concentration was selected based on preliminary testing of multiple siRNA concentrations, where 10 µM yielded optimal delivery and knockdown efficiency. Zygotes were then transferred in 5.7 µL of the siRNA/Opti-MEM solution to an electroporation slide equipped with platinum plate electrodes (15 mm length, 1 mm gap, 1.5 mm height; Bulldog Bio, Portsmouth, NH, USA). Electroporated control zygotes were transferred in 5.7 uL of Opti-MEM alone. Electroporation was performed using the following parameters: poring pulses − 20 V, 6 pulses, 1.5 ms duration, 50 ms intervals, 10% decay rate, and transfer pulse − 3 V/mm, 5 pulses, 50 ms duration, 50 ms intervals, 40% decay rate. Therefore, this study aimed to evaluate DNA methylation in the oocytes as well as the embryos produced from the same methionine-supplemented mature ewes. Notably, we identified 2,056 DMCs in the oocytes of methionine-treated versus control ewes, with 2,034 being hypomethylated. While a methyl-donor diet would be expected to increase methylation, the observed predominance of hypomethylation in germ cells is intriguing and aligns with our previous findings in sperm. Gross et al. [ 32 31 31 46 47 In contrast to the widespread hypomethylation observed in oocytes, we found that nearly all DMCs in embryos were hypermethylated, with only a single hypomethylated DMC. This shift in methylation status is consistent with the well-established process of epigenetic reprogramming that occurs following fertilization. Upon fertilization, the parental genomes undergo extensive demethylation, erasing most epigenetic marks to establish a pluripotent state in the early embryo. Then, during gastrulation in the embryo, a new epigenetic landscape is established, which plays a key role in driving cellular differentiation in the conceptus [ 48 49 50 51 52 Effects of maternal diet on methylation patterns in oocytes and embryos While over 2,000 DMCs were identified in the oocytes produced from methionine-supplemented versus control ewes, only 211 DMCs, all of which were hypomethylated, were found to be associated with 15 uncharacterized genes. Mitochondria and the nuclear epigenome engage in bidirectional crosstalk, where mitochondrial processes mediate epigenetic changes, and nuclear epigenetic regulation influences mitochondrial function. This relationship is key in stress responses, longevity, and cellular metabolism [ 76 77 Mitochondria are critical in supplying the intermediate metabolites required for nuclear epigenetic modifications. The regulation of these processes relies heavily on the availability of methyl donors, with the one-carbon cycle being central to linking metabolism and epigenetic regulation. In this pathway, methionine acts as a key methyl donor, providing S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) for DNA methylation reactions. SAM is generated through the methionine-homocysteine cycle in the cytosol. However, this cycle depends on the folate cycle and ATP, which are both reliant on mitochondrial metabolism [ 76 78 MT-CO2 79 80 Importantly, alterations in mtDNA methylation have been associated with various multifactorial diseases, including cardiovascular diseases [ 81 82 83 Limitations of this study include challenges associated with the inherently low DNA quantity in oocytes and embryos, which resulted in suboptimal sequencing depth. This led to reduced and variable alignment rates across samples, with average alignment rates of 27% for oocytes and 33% for embryos. This variability introduced challenges in downstream analysis, as the total number of cytosines available for methylation assessment was lower than expected. Consequently, some biologically relevant DMCs may have been undetected, potentially underestimating the full extent of methionine-induced methylation changes. Future studies could benefit from optimized library preparation to improve sequencing efficiency and provide a more comprehensive assessment of DNA methylation dynamics in these low-input cell types. Conclusions In conclusion, this study provides novel insights into the impact of maternal methionine supplementation on DNA methylation patterns in oocytes and embryos, highlighting potential epigenetic mechanisms through which maternal diet influences offspring development. Compared with hypermethylation in embryos, the widespread hypomethylation observed in oocytes suggests a complex interplay between maternal nutrition and epigenetic reprogramming. The identification of differentially methylated genes involved in key developmental processes, including neurodevelopment, cellular organization, and metabolism, underscores the potential long-term implications of maternal dietary interventions on fetal programming. Furthermore, the observed changes in mitochondrial DNA methylation reinforce the role of mitochondrial epigenetics in linking maternal nutrition to offspring health.
